list_definition.definition: to grow too big or too old for

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: My son has outgrown all his clothes.

list_ex_of_english: Payments cannot be made to replace clothing or shoes worn out or outgrown in the normal way.
When it comes to exploring the world around her she is dependent upon others and reliant upon a pushchair she has now outgrown.
His taste has outgrown the sect of what was then called ' progressive rock' and has become more open, ' global'.
There is no doubt that the common informer, as part of our civil and legal life, has long outgrown his usefulness—if he ever had any.
Unfortunately, the son has almost outgrown his father and has become something of an embarrassment to his parents.
Obviously, they have outgrown or outworn their previous civilian clothing.
Though enthymemic, and less salient in the text than the stor y of the society that outgrows its primar y rules, this is clearly an argument.
The 10-year rule is, to me, far too limiting on premises which could, in a much shorter period, be outgrown.
